abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Human Capital Technical
            Assistance (HCTA) Project for Slovak Republic were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk
            to development outcome was substantial, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            designing a project that depends on the permanence and
            efficacy of a handful of individuals is a high-risk
            proposition. More work up front, and where that was not
            possible, early on in implementation, to build support for
            the project at the technical level will have resulted in
            greater ownership. The amount the loan for the HCTA Project
            was probably adequate for the actual tasks, but not enough
            to catch and hold the interest of ministers once the project
            champions had moved on. Also, the fact that the project was
            not incremental to regular ministry budgets further reduced
            interest. If it had been possible to decentralize the
            project steering committee to a lower level (perhaps
            department heads), the amount of money might have been
            enough to gain attention, and built greater ownership. But
            this will have required more work done up front to build
            ownership for project activities. Traditional Bank
            investment projects have a lot of rules and are a lot of
            work to implement. As European funds with fewer strings
            became more available, the ministries could turn to other
            sources to fund activities (such as information technology
            investment) originally contemplated under the project and
            the pressure to implement the Bank funded project grew still
            less urgent.
